channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Marine Veteran Held in Iran Assails ‘Serial Hostage-Taking’
item.description: Amir Hekmati, of Flint, Mich., who has been imprisoned in Iran for more than three years, made the remarks in letter to congressional leaders dictated by telephone.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Saudis Announce Halt to Yemen Bombing Campaign
item.description: The Saudi Defense Ministry said the objectives in its bombing of Yemen’s Iran-backed Houthi rebels, which threatened to flare up a broader regional conflict, had been achieved.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MARK MAZZETTI
item.media:description: A Saudi soldier at the border with Yemen, fired a mortar shell toward Houthi rebels on Tuesday.

item.title: Xi Jinping Plans to Fund Pakistan
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China had announced plans to contribute $46 billion for energy and infrastructure projects, an influx that could be a huge benefit to the Pakistani economy.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: White House Acknowledges Armenian Genocide, but Avoids the Term
item.description: President Obama’s continued resistance to the word stood in contrast to Pope Francis, who recently called the massacres “the first genocide of the 20th century” and equated it to mass killings by the Nazis and Soviets.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Open Source: Sighs of Relief From Yemen, Mixed With Fears of More Conflict
item.description: Yemeni bloggers expressed relief that the Saudi-led air campaign had finally come to an end, tempered by concern that the conflict was far from over.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Mandera Journal: Kenya Envisions a Border Wall That Keeps Shabab Violence Out
item.description: After attacks by the Shabab, extremist Somali group, killed hundreds in Kenya, plans for a security barrier stir intense debate in a town where the two sides of the border are highly interconnected.
item.dc:creator: ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:credit: Will Swanson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A the end of each day, the Kenyan police close the border gate between Mandera and Bula Hawa, Somalia. The two sides of the border are highly interconnected.

item.title: Study Finds Low Cost in Reducing Methane Emissions
item.description: Researchers say that stopping leaks of methane, a potent greenhouse gas, is a major untapped opportunity for combating climate change.
item.dc:creator: JOHN SCHWARTZ

item.title: India, Seeking a Boost, Plans to Put Its ‘Idle Gold’ to Work
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi would like to monetize the roughly 20,000 tons of gold thought to be in private hands, 2,500 tons of it in major Hindu temples.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Donated gold jewelry was put up for auction this week at a Hindu temple in Mumbai, India.

item.title: One Israeli Soldier, 23 Namesakes and a Day of Remembrance
item.description: At least 23 babies have been named for Gil’ad, a lieutenant in the Israeli Army who was killed in 1973. On Wednesday, members of the Gil’ad generation will gather to remember him.
item.dc:creator: JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers prepared to place the national flag on graves at the Mount Herzl military cemetery in Jerusalem on Sunday, three days before Israel's Memorial Day.

item.title: Egyptian Court Sentences Mohamed Morsi to 20 Years in Prison
item.description: Mr. Morsi, the deposed president, was sentenced after being convicted of charges stemming from a night of bloody street fighting between his supporters and opponents in 2012.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and MERNA THOMAS

item.title: Israel to Remove Name of Slain Palestinian Teenager From Memorial
item.description: The addition of Muhammad Abu Khdeir’s name to the state’s memorial to victims of hostile acts had drawn criticism from his father and an Israeli activist group.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Suha Abu Khdeir, whose son Muhammad was burned to death by three Israelis last summer.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Migrants Face Fortress Europe’s Deadly Moat
item.description: Thousands of migrants are dying at sea because of inhumane E.U. policy.
item.dc:creator: KENAN MALIK

item.title: Former SS Member, on Trial in Germany, Says He Was ‘Morally Complicit’ at Auschwitz
item.description: Oskar Gröning, 93, is charged with complicity in the murder of 300,000 prisoners at the Nazi death camp in 1944.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Oskar Gröning, a former SS member who worked at Auschwitz-Birkenau, during a break on the first day of his trial in Lüneburg, Germany, on Tuesday.

item.title: Migrant Boat Captain Steered Toward Tragedy in Mediterranean, Authorities Say
item.description: Survivors said the captain made “wrong maneuvers” and collided with a rescue ship, precipitating a capsize that the authorities say killed more than 800.
item.dc:creator: JIM YARDLEY and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Migrants who survived a boat sinking over the weekend arrived at the Sicilian port city of Catania early on Tuesday.

item.title: As Cash Dwindles, Greece Negotiates With Gazprom on ‘Energy Cooperation’
item.description: The meeting came amid speculation of a possible multibillion-dollar gas pipeline deal by Athens and Moscow, which could provide Greece needed money.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Aleksei B. Miller, center, the Gazprom chief executive, meeting on Tuesday with Alexis Tsipras, left, Greece's prime minister, and Panagiotis Lafazanis, the country's energy minister.

item.title: South African Army Deployed in Areas Hit by Anti-Immigrant Violence
item.description: The government has faced criticism that it responded too slowly to attacks that have claimed seven lives.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: Men suspected of killing a Mozambican immigrant were arraigned in Johannesburg on Tuesday.

item.title: China’s Economy Puts New Pressure on Its Lopsided Job Market
item.description: With its uneven pockets of supply and demand and decline in agriculture jobs, China’s huge manufacturing sector is showing new signs of stress.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wang Junping, front row on right, was given lessons at an employment agency on cleaning Beijing’s subway system.

item.title: Hundreds of Chinese Cities Don’t Meet Air Standards, Report Finds
item.description: More than 90 percent of 360 Chinese cities failed to meet national air quality standards in the first three months of this year, according to a study released by Greenpeace East Asia.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Morning exercises on a polluted day in March in Jiaozuo, Henan Province, China.

item.title: Co-Pilot’s Coffee Spill Blamed in Plunge of Serbian President’s Plane
item.description: In trying to clean up the spill, the co-pilot accidentally activated an instrument that led to a brief engine shutdown, investigators said.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA BERENDT

item.title: Russian Workers Take Aim at Putin as Economy Exacts Its Toll
item.description: Subdued for a time by a surge in national pride after the annexation of Crimea, discontent over unpaid wages and forced vacations has generated a wave of labor actions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: The Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, in Moscow last week. Workers across Russia are starting to protest against unpaid wages and go on strike, in the first nationwide backlash against Mr. Putin's economic policies.
